@treasuresETH @undacappn @Nate_Rivers @mart1ndoteth Ok this is actually scary. One signature to validate multiple transactions. This attack in that scenario is just getting started. People can easily farm signatures via mints and leverage them to drain wallets.

@undacappn @Nate_Rivers @treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth Thanks for the analogy. According to your analogy @Nate_Rivers would have signed 10 times on a phished link for 10 NFTs he owns? Not sure how many NFTs he lost, but there should be 1-1 mapping of NFT to signature spoofing according to the logic mentioned here.
@treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth From same victim* 10 signatures of same victim for 10 stolen NFTs.

@treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth Coming back to this. If each listing requires a signature, then for every NFT that was stolen (from same victim) there should be a corresponding signature to farm by the attacker right? Thus if 10 NFTs are stolen attacker should have 10 signatures right?
@NadavAHollander What is the purpose of a signature if someone can replicate it? Ideally no one should be able to relay a signature right?

@undacappn @Nate_Rivers @treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth Yes, the thing which confuses me the most is what is the purpose of signature if someone can relay the signature? It beats the purpose of having signature! Thus I am still not convinced that this was just a phishing and not a bug in the contract.

RT @JackRhysider: The brakes on a car are only there to enable us to go faster. 

The security team should should be looked at the same wayâ€¦
@Nate_Rivers @treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth The NFTs that were lost, do you know if you listed the collection before? Also, the ones which were not stolen did Opensea have access to it?

@treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth You are right with regards to signature. One has to sign for every NFT. But, the individual still mentioned this a month ago - "There is a bug in the WyvernTokenTransferProxy approval that allows anyone to transfer NFTs to other wallets" may be this doesn't need a signature?

@treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth No, if you list it once and gave access to Opensea then you don't need to list other NFTs. That's why you pay for transaction only once and not every time to list a NFT from same collection.
@treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth So itâ€™s possible you legitimately gave access to Opensea to do a transaction i.e. sell a NFT and you signed it with your keys because this is by function.

@treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth Obviously it requires a signature by the owner. When you list a NFT via opensea, you authorize opensea rights to sell or transfer. If the bug is in the contract and if you didnâ€™t revoke the access, opensea still has access to your NFT and the specific collection.
@treasuresETH @mart1ndoteth What proves it was a phishing attack and not a bug which was exploited?
@mart1ndoteth @treasuresETH https://t.co/qveYvjV181
@Nate_Rivers @pranksy @opensea Opensea punting on phishing to save their ass.

@treasuresETH Itâ€™s not phishing, it was an opensea bug! They are just trying to punt it to phishing.
